Selective C-O bond activation in biomass-derived furanic compounds is essential for biomass upgrading. Hydrogenolysis of furfuryl alcohol (FFA) provides two value-added chemicals 1,5-pentanediol (1,5-PDO) and 1,2-pentanediol (1,2-PDO), the generation of both involve selective C-O bond cleavage of FFA, but the respective catalytic active sites still remain obscure. Here we prepared a series of potassium-modified basic oxide supported Cu catalysts and found the product distribution of 1,2-PDO/1,5-PDO selectivity ratio decreased with the rise of K loadings. Various characterization techniques show that the Cu/MgO mainly consists of Cu nanoparticles, while the 2 K-Cu/MgO is dominant by oxidized Cu species especially Cu+. It is proposed that the selective C-O bond cleavage of the furan ring of FFA to 1,5-PDO over basic oxide supported Cu catalysts is attributed to Cu+ species, while the formation of 1,2-PDO is dependent on Cu nanoparticles. This work sheds light on the selective C-O bond activation in the biomass-derived furanic compounds. Graphical Abstract Keywords C-O bond activation Potassium Furfuryl alcohol 1,5-Pentanediol 1,2-Pentanediol Hydrogenolysis Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Biomass conversion has been widely accepted as a green and sustainable process for the production of fuels and chemicals in view of the replacement of their production from fossil resources.[1–3] As biomass-derived platform molecules usually have high oxygen content, selective transformation of C-O bond in oxygen containing molecules is thus the key for biomass upgrading.[4–6] Furfuryl alcohol (FFA), an essential large-scale industrialized compound from hydrogenation of biobased furfural, can be converted to many valuable chemicals.[7] For instance, 1,5-pentanediol (1,5-PDO) and 1,2-pentanediol (1,2-PDO), can be produced by the hydrogenolysis of FFA, both are very useful chemicals. Owing to the use of 1,5-PDO for industrial polyester and polyurethane, the selective hydrogenolysis of FFA to 1,5-PDO is thus more desired.[8,9] Cu catalysts have displayed activity in the ring-opening hydrogenolysis of FFA or furfural to pentanediols.[10–17] Of those reported Cu catalysts supported on basic oxide, the ring-opening of furan ring was attributed to the basic sites and the reaction activity was depended on the metallic Cu species. Both Hu group and Zhao group showed that basic sites of CuMgAl catalyst aided the ring-opening of the furan ring of FFA to pentanediols by in-situ DRIFTS characterization.[10,12] Those basic oxide supported Cu catalysts all displayed a higher 1,2-PDO selectivity than 1,5-PDO towards the hydrogenolysis of FFA. Liu group recently reported that the Brønsted acidic sites of the Cu/MFI catalyst attacked the C-O-C of the furan ring of FFA and promoted the C-O cleavage to pentanediols, the synergistic catalysis between Brønsted acid and balanced Cu0–Cu+ realized a much higher selectivity 1,5-PDO than 1,2-PDO. [16,17] However, how to selectively control the C-O bond activation of furan ring of FFA to 1,5-PDO or 1,2-PDO is still not clear. Particularly, due to the presence of dual C–O bonds in the furan ring of FFA ( Scheme 1), the respective catalytic active sites to selectively activate the C2-O bond or the C5-O bond which will result in the formation of 1,5-PDO or the formation of 1,2-PDO need investigations. The addition of alkali metals into heterogenous metal catalysts has been proven as an effective method to improve the catalytic activity and tune the product distribution.[18,19] The presence of alkali metals enables the modification of the electronic and chemical properties of the active metal sites, which greatly affects the adsorption and dissociation of molecules and the catalytic performances.[20–25] In this work, we prepared a series of Cu catalysts supported on basic oxide (including MgO, La2O3 and mixed oxide MgO-La2O3) and their potassium-modified catalysts with different K loadings. These catalysts were applied to the hydrogenolysis of FFA reaction, and the impacts of K on the product distribution of 1,2-PDO and 1,5-PDO were studied. Characterizations including X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM), hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) and X-Ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were performed on the representative catalysts Cu/MgO and 2 K-Cu/MgO to study the changes on the physical structures brought by the introduction of K and reveal the active sites for selective ring-opening hydrogenolysis of FFA. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation Co-precipitation method was used to prepare the catalysts. Cu(NO3)2▪3 H2O (15.0 mmol) and Mg(NO3)2▪6 H2O (60.0 mmol) were dissolved in deionized water (50 mL), followed by slow dropwise of alkaline solution containing NaOH (8 mol/L) and Na2CO3 (0.25 mol/L). The pH value of the resulting solution was maintained at 10.0±0.2 and the solution temperature was kept at 70 ℃ for 24 h. Then the solution was filtered until the pH value of filtrate was ∼7, and the resulting precipitant was dried. A certain amount of KNO3 was loaded on the precipitant by incipient wetness impregnation method and the resulting solid was dried. Then the solid was calcined at 600 ℃ for 3 h with an air flow of 30 mL/min and a ramp rate of 5 °C/min and reduced in hydrogen atmosphere (H2/N2,10 v/v%) at 200 ℃ for 2 h, affording xK-Cu/MgO. x represents the nominal K loadings, which are 0, 0.5 wt% and 2 wt%. The sample without the addition of K species was named as Cu/MgO. 2 K-Cu/MgO-Reg was prepared by treating the used 2 K-Cu/MgO catalyst at 600 ℃ for 3 h with an air flow of 30 mL/min and a ramp rate of 5 °C/min and reduced in hydrogen atmosphere (H2/N2,10 v/v%) at 200 ℃ for 2 h. xK-Cu/La2O3 (x = 0, 0.5, 2) were prepared similar to that of xK-Cu/MgO except with La(NO3)3▪6 H2O (21.6 mmol) and Cu(NO3)2▪3 H2O (16.6 mmol) as the precursor. xK-Cu/MgO-La2O3 (x= 0, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2) were also prepared except with Cu(NO3)2▪3 H2O (16.2 mmol), Mg(NO3)2▪6 H2O (38.8 mmol) and La(NO3)3▪6 H2O (15.0 mmol) as the precursors. The Cu loadings of these samples were determined by ICP, as shown in Table S1. 2.2 Characterization The K and Cu loadings were determined by the inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES). X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) was recorded on a PANanlytical X’pert-Pro diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation in the range of 10°-80°. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) measurements were carried out using a Micromeritics Autochem II 2920. Each sample (50 mg) was placed in a U-shaped quartz reactor. To remove traces of water in the samples, it was purged with flowing Ar (10 cm3/min) at 120 ℃ for 2 h and then cooled down to room temperature. Then the gas was switched to H2/Ar (10%, flowing rate: 10 cm3/min), which was heated from room temperature to 600 ℃ with a heating rate of 10 ℃/min. The H2 consumption was quantified by thermal conductivity detector (TCD) during the reduction. CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) measurements were carried out using Micromeritics Autochem 2910. Before adsorption, each sample was placed in a U-shaped quartz reactor and heated to 200 ℃ for 1 hour with flowing O2/He (5 v/v%, 10 cm3/min), and then cooled down to 100 ℃. The sample was exposed to CO2 for 0.5 h and was maintained in a He flow for 0.5 h to remove physiosorbed CO2. Afterwards, the temperature was increased linearly at a rate of 10 ℃/min to 700 ℃ for recording the signal of CO2. Aberration corrected high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC-HAADF−STEM) and corresponding energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping were measured on a JEOL JEM ARM200F instrument. X-Ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) experiments were conducted on a Thermo Fisher ESCALAB 250Xi, and auger electron spectra were collected using an aluminum anode (Al Ka = 1486.6 eV). All the obtained XPS spectra were calibrated by the adventitious carbon C 1 s band (284.8 eV), for correcting the energy shift caused by electrostatic charging. 2.3 Catalytic reaction The hydrogenation of FFA was performed in a stainless-steel autoclave (25 mL) equipped with a pressure gage and magnetic stirrer. A mixture of FFA, catalyst, solvent and dodecane as internal standard were placed into a quartz vessel, which was then put into the autoclave. The autoclave was sealed and purged with hydrogen at least three times and finally charged with hydrogen at a pressure of 3 MPa. The reaction time commenced after reaching the set temperature. After the reaction, the autoclave was cooled down to room temperature followed by releasing the remaining hydrogen gas. The product was then condensed and analyzed by gas chromatography (7890B, Agilent) equipped with a capillary DB-FFAP column (30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 μm) and a flame ionization detector (FID). 3 Results and discussion 3.1. Catalyst performances. The hydrogenolysis of FFA was performed at 150 °C with 3 MPa of H2 for 4 h under batch conditions with isopropanol as the solvent, the catalytic performances are shown in Table 1. In order to study the effect of potassium on the product distribution in the hydrogenolysis of FFA, the molar ratio of 1,2-PDO/1,5-PDO for all the samples were compared. With the increase of K loading in the xK-Cu/MgO (x = 0, 0.5, 2) catalysts, 1,5-PDO selectivity rose from 21.0% to 36.4%, on the contrary, 1,2-PDO selectivity dropped from 43.3% to 22.4% (Entry 1–3). Correspondingly, the 1,2-PDO/1,5-PDO ratio decreased from 2.0 to 0.62. The total pentanediol selectivity is competitive among the reported catalysts (Table S2). Hydrogenation products tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) and 2-methylfuran (2-MF) were also detected and their selectivities were also listed in Table 1. Although the formation of THFA increased and the formation of 2-MF decreased with the rise of K content over the xK-Cu/MgO, the aim of this work was the investigation on the selective hydrogenolysis of C-O bond of the furan ring of FFA, discussions on the formation of these two products were thus not discussed. Besides, 2-methyltetrahydrofuran (2-MeTHF) and products of the hydrogenolysis of 2-MF like 1-pentanol and 2-pentanol relatively in small amounts were also detected. Others in Table 1 include 2-MeTHF, 1-pentanol, 2-pentanol and unidentified products. Significantly, the xK-Cu/La2O3 (x = 0, 0.5, 2) and the xK-Cu/MgO-La2O3 (x = 0, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2) also showed a gradual decrease in the 1,2-PDO/1,5-PDO ratio, from 1.7 to 0.89 (Entry 6–8) and from 2.3 to 0.92 (Entry 9–13) respectively. These results show the increase of K loadings in the basic oxide supported Cu catalysts promoted the formation of 1,5-PDO and simultaneously suppressed the formation of 1,2-PDO. All the Cu catalysts with the absence of K showed a much higher selectivity of 1,2-PDO than 1,5-PDO, consistent with the previous reported basic oxide supported Cu catalysts (CuMgAl and Cu@MgO-La2O3).[10,12] Besides, the reaction activity decreased with the rise of K loadings, suggesting that the K species suppressed the hydrogen activation, which could result from the decreased ability in hydrogen dissociation over Cu species. Further studies were carried out on the 2 K-Cu/MgO due to the higher 1,5-PDO selectivity. The 2 K-Cu/MgO completely lost its activity in the second run (Entry 4). The temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) measurements showed that the used 2 K-Cu/MgO catalyst gave much higher intensity of CO2 evolution than the pristine 2 K-Cu/MgO (Figure S1), which suggests that the formation of humins on the surface of catalyst during the reaction.[26,27] We infer that the active sites were completely covered by humins which resulted in the loss of catalytic activity. Regeneration was thus carried out by calcination of the used 2 K-Cu/MgO catalyst. The resulting catalyst 2 K-Cu/MgO-Reg showed catalytic activity towards hydrogenolysis of FFA, but the dominant product was 1,2-PDO with 1,2-PDO/1,5-PDO selectivity ratio of 2.7 (Entry 5), much higher than that of the 2 K-Cu/MgO (0.62). To investigate the relationship between the electronic structure and product distribution of 1,2-PDO and 1,5-PDO for these potassium-modified Cu catalysts, characterizations were performed for Cu/MgO, 2 K-Cu/MgO and 2 K-Cu/MgO-Reg. 3.2. Characterizations. Fig. 1 showed the XRD patterns of all samples, and the analyses of diffraction peaks for all the samples by comparison with the standard substances were illustrated in Figure S2. Typical MgO diffraction peaks (PDF# 75–0447) were observed in all the samples. The Cu/MgO displayed characteristic peaks at 43.3°, 50.4°, 74.0° which are indexed to metallic Cu (PDF# 89–2838), and weak diffraction peaks at 36.4° and 42.3° assigning to Cu2O (PDF# 78–2076) were also observed. Significantly, strong diffraction peaks indexed to Cu2O and CuO (PDF# 89–5899) were observed for 2 K-Cu/MgO, and the peaks assigning to metallic Cu disappeared, indicating that the presence of K species promoted the formation of copper oxides (CuOx). Besides, the strong intensity of Cu2O and CuO peaks suggests high crystallinity and the presence of larger amounts of CuOx in the 2 K-Cu/MgO than in the Cu/MgO. While only metallic Cu species were seen in the diffraction patterns of the 2 K-Cu/MgO-Reg. K-related phases were not observed in these samples, suggesting that K species were well dispersed. HAADF-STEM measurements were carried out to study the dispersion of Cu species on the surface of MgO. For the Cu/MgO catalyst, the STEM images showed that Cu nanoparticles with an average size of 5.0 nm were dispersed on the surface of MgO ( Fig. 2a). Linear-scanned energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (LS-EDS) of a selected particle showed that the intensity of Cu was much higher than that of Mg and O (Figure S3), suggesting that Cu nanoparticles were located at the surface of MgO. The AC-STEM images demonstrated highly dispersed monolayers of Cu species and isolated Cu atoms on the surface of MgO (Fig. 2b). The Cu atoms were further confirmed by the contrast analysis of selected sites (Figure S4). The generation of isolated single atoms might be due to the high temperature calcination.[28–30] A d-spacing of 0.245 nm in a monolayer corresponding to the Cu2O (111) and a d-spacing of 0.208 nm in a particle assigning to metallic Cu (111) was observed in Figure S5,[31] consistent with the XRD results. For the 2 K-Cu/MgO, the STEM images showed no existence of Cu particles, indicating that Cu species are well dispersed (Fig. 2c). The AC-STEM images of 2 K-Cu/MgO showed the presence of monolayers of Cu2O(111) and CuO(111) which are confirmed by the d-spacings of the monolayers of 0.246 nm and 0.252 nm, respectively (Fig. 2d).[16] EDS mappings of 2 K-Cu/MgO showed that Cu and K elements were well scattered on the surface of MgO (Figure S6). These results indicate the presence of K boosted the dispersion of Cu species and the formation of CuOx. The 2 K-Cu/MgO-Reg showed an average Cu nanoparticle size of 8.2 nm (Fig. 2e), larger than that of the 2 K-Cu/MgO, which can be attributed to the presence of carbon species on the catalyst that promoted the aggregation of Cu species during calcination. Well dispersed monolayers of Cu species and isolated Cu atoms were observed in the AC-STEM image of 2 K-Cu/MgO-Reg (Fig. 2f), like that of the Cu/MgO. The EDS mappings of 2 K-Cu/MgO-Reg also confirmed the co-existence of Cu nanoparticles and isolated Cu atoms and showed well dispersed K species (Figure S7). In order to study the reducibility and the content of different copper species, H2-TPR measurements were performed. The TPR profiles were illustrated in Fig. 3. The Cu/MgO catalyst showed two reduction peaks at 143 ℃ (α type) and 183 ℃ (β type) that can be attributed to the reduction of CuO to Cu2O and the reduction of Cu2O to Cu, respectively.[32–34] Unlike TPR profiles of the Cu/MgO, the 2 K-Cu/MgO displayed one wide unsymmetrical reduction peak which can be roughly fitted into two peaks at 255 ℃ and 310 ℃, indicating that the presence of K markedly inhibited the reduction of CuOx. These results suggest the presence of strong electronic interactions between the K species and the CuOx in the 2 K-Cu/MgO, which led to the formation of a new interface consisting of K-O-Cu layer.[21,25,35,36] The formation of K-O-Cu resulted in strong electron polarization on the catalyst surface, which made the reduction of CuOx much difficult.[37,38] The 2 K-Cu/MgO-Reg presented two reduction peaks at 168 ℃ and 188 ℃, slightly higher than those of the Cu/MgO, but much lower than those of the 2 K-Cu/MgO, indicating that the K-O-Cu interactions in the 2 K-Cu/MgO-Reg barely exist. H2 consumption results were listed in Table 2. The total H2 consumption increased from 2 K-Cu/MgO-Reg, Cu/MgO, to 2 K-Cu/MgO. The Cu2O content in the samples can be estimated from the H2 consumption of the β type peak, which also showed a rising trend from 0.47 mmol/g (2 K-Cu/MgO-Reg), 0.98 mmol/g (Cu/MgO) to 2.71 mmol/g (2 K-Cu/MgO). To examine the changes in chemical state of Cu species, XPS was also conducted for the Cu/MgO and the 2 K-Cu/MgO. The surface Cu contents are quantified and compared by XPS (Table S1). Although these two samples shared similar Cu loadings of about 24 wt% in the bulk phase, the Cu/MgO showed a relatively lower Cu surface content (4.3 wt%) than the 2 K-Cu/MgO (4.8 wt%), suggestive of a higher dispersion of Cu species in the 2 K-Cu/MgO. As shown in Fig. 4a, Cu 2p spectra were deconvoluted by fitting peaks with a Gaussian method. For the Cu/MgO, the bands at 932.1 eV and 952.2 eV are ascribed to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 of Cu0/+, while the bands at 933.5 eV and 953.9 eV to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 of Cu2+ with satellite peaks at 941.1 eV and 961.1 eV.[39] All the peaks of the 2 K-Cu/MgO showed a positive shift of about 0.4 eV in comparison to that of the Cu/MgO, indicating a higher Cu oxidation states in the 2 K-Cu/MgO. Cu LMM X-ray-induced Auger electron spectroscopy (XAES) of the Cu/MgO and the 2 K-Cu/MgO was carried out for further discrimination and quantification of the major Cu0 and Cu+ species. From the deconvolution results of the Cu/MgO, the peaks at 912.4, 916.7, and 918.2 eV belong to Cu+, Cu2+, and Cu0 species.[39] The molar ratio of Cu0/Cu+ was calculated by integrating the Gaussian peak fitting of XAES ( Table 3). The calculation showed that the Cu/MgO had a much lower Cu+/Cu0 ratio (0.38) than the 2 K-Cu/MgO (0.87), indicating the presence of K boosted the formation of Cu+, which is in line with the XRD and TPR results. CO2-temperature programmed desorption (TPD) measurements were carried out for Cu/MgO and 2 K-Cu/MgO, the results are shown in Fig. 5. After the introduction of K, the total basic sites increased from 5.88 μmol/g to 7.63 μmol/g (Table 3), and the desorption temperatures negatively shifted from 291℃ to 257℃ for the weak basic sites and from 460℃ to 413℃ for the medium basic sites. The strong basic sites at 550℃ did not show much difference in the desorption temperature, but the quantity clearly decreased. These results indicate the presence of K not only changed the quantity also the strength of basic sites. By comparing the quantity of basic sites by the introduction of K (Table 3), we found that the strong basic increased significantly, on the opposite, the weak basic sites decreased, the strong basic sites can be attributed to the adsorption of CO2 on low-coordinated Cu+ species based on the work of CO2 hydrogenation.[40,41] 3.3 Discussion. More investigations were performed to find out the relation between the electronic structure and the product distribution of 1,2-PDO and 1,5-PDO. We found that the content of Cu2O calculated from H2-TPR displayed a negative linear relation to the 1,2-PDO/1,5-PDO selectivity ratio with a fitted R2 of 0.98, as shown in Fig. 6a. Besides, the 2 K-Cu/MgO showed a much higher Cu+/Cu0 ratio than the Cu/MgO calculated from XAES. This indicates the Cu2O species are positively related to the 1,5-PDO selectivity. Co-based catalysts have shown intrinsic activity towards the selective hydrogenolysis of FFA to 1,5-PDO, and the electron-enriched Co2+ species were widely accepted as the key for the ring-opening of FFA, which means the Co2+ species promoted the formation of 1,5-PDO.[42–46] We thus proposed that the presence of Cu2O species played a crucial role in the selective cleavage of C2-O bond of FFA to 1,5-PDO. On the other hand, we infer that the Cu particles were conducive to the formation of 1,2-PDO. Due to the well-dispersed Cu species and the absence of Cu particles in the STEM images of the 2 K-Cu/MgO, we assumed that the mean Cu particle size was 0.5 nm for an easier comparison with the 2 K-Cu/MgO-Reg (8.2 nm) and the Cu/MgO (5.0 nm). As shown in Fig. 6b, the Cu particle size is strongly positively related to the 1,2-PDO/1,5-PDO ratio, which means larger Cu particle size enhanced the 1,2-PDO selectivity and simultaneously suppressed the 1,5-PDO selectivity, indicating the selective of C5-O bond activation in FFA to 1,2-PDO is positively related to the size of Cu particle size. Differently, the conversion under identical reaction conditions showed a volcanic curve with the rise of particle size (Fig. 6c), indicative of the presence of particle size effect. This is in line with a previous report showing that the TOF of the 4.65 nm-Cu particle catalyst was the highest among the 3.5 nm to the 12 nm-Cu particle catalysts towards the hydrogenolysis of FFA.[12] The introduction of K not only altered Cu+ content and Cu particle size, also changed the basic properties. By comparing with the Cu/MgO, the total basic sites slightly increased in the 2 K-Cu/MgO, and noteworthily, the strong basic sites increased, and the weak basic sites decreased. We infer that the changes in the strength of basic sites might affect the adsorption of FFA and desorption of products resulting in a lowered reaction activity based on previous reports,[10,12] and put no significant impacts on the selective C-O bond cleavage. The selective C-O cleavage of FFA was strongly dependent on the Cu species, the Cu+ aided the formation of 1,5-PDO, and the Cu particles promoted the formation of 1,2-PDO. 4 Conclusion We have presented that the introduction of K species in basic oxide (including MgO, La2O3, MgO-La2O3) supported Cu catalysts altered the product distribution between 1,2-PDO and 1,5-PDO towards hydrogenolysis of FFA with the preferred hydrogenolysis product changed from 1,2-PDO to 1,5-PDO. Physical characterizations show that the addition of K in Cu/MgO promoted the formation K-O-Cu species, which boosted the dispersion Cu species with enhanced content of Cu+ and less Cu nanoparticles. The presence of K also changed the strength of basic properties with an increase in strong basic sites and a decrease in weak basic sites, which might affect the reaction activity. It is found that the selective C-O bond activation of the furan ring of FFA is dependent on Cu species, the formation of 1,5-PDO is attributed to the Cu+, and the production of 1,2-PDO is promoted by Cu nanoparticles. coredata.dc:description: Selective C-O bond activation in biomass-derived furanic compounds is essential for biomass upgrading. Hydrogenolysis of furfuryl alcohol (FFA) provides two value-added chemicals 1,5-pentanediol (1,5-PDO) and 1,2-pentanediol (1,2-PDO), the generation of both involve selective C-O bond cleavage of FFA, but the respective catalytic active sites still remain obscure. Here we prepared a series of potassium-modified basic oxide supported Cu catalysts and found the product distribution of 1,2-PDO/1,5-PDO selectivity ratio decreased with the rise of K loadings. Various characterization techniques show that the Cu/MgO mainly consists of Cu nanoparticles, while the 2 K-Cu/MgO is dominant by oxidized Cu species especially Cu+. It is proposed that the selective C-O bond cleavage of the furan ring of FFA to 1,5-PDO over basic oxide supported Cu catalysts is attributed to Cu+ species, while the formation of 1,2-PDO is dependent on Cu nanoparticles. This work sheds light on the selective C-O bond activation in the biomass-derived furanic compounds.
coredata.dc:title: Effect of potassium in copper catalysts on selective C–O bond activation of furfuryl alcohol
